text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

SPEAKER: Offices
and the ways we use
them are constantly evolving.

There is nothing natural
or fixed about the spaces
where we work.
[WHISTLE BLOWS]

In fact, reporting to a building
to do knowledge-based work
is a relatively-recent idea.

AGUSTIN CHEVEZ: When you look
at the buildings in the city,

you take for granted that
work occurs in the office.

Then you realize that
work has occupied so many

different spaces, so many
different environments--

that the office is just a short
blink in the history of time.

SPEAKER: Architect and workplace
design researcher Agustin

Chevez says we need to
remind ourselves that offices
had to be invented.

And over time, they have evolved
to meet our own changing needs
and expectations.

Now that COVID-19 has upended
office life worldwide,

we thought understanding the
ways the office has evolved

could help us frame the
changes happening today.

With the help of historians,
architects, and stories

from HBR readers, we took
a look at four key moments

in the history of
modern offices.

In the 1960s, the Herman
Miller Furniture Company
introduced the Action Office.

It was a flexible combination
of desks, tables, and walls--

offering workers
flexibility and privacy.

But the need for office
space was growing quickly.

Other furniture companies
introduced copycat versions

of the Action Office,
and companies eventually

started using them to simply
jam more people into less space.
The modern cubicle was born.

CLEMENCIA VILLAMIL: Now, when
I started with a cubicle,
it looked nice when I walked in.

But when I started working, it
didn't help my productivity.

SPEAKER: Clemencia Villamil,
who worked in HR in Venezuela,

remembers transitioning
from a big office

to the isolation
of cubicle land.

CLEMENCIA VILLAMIL: It was
difficult to make that link,

with people being in
a cubicle and being
separated from everybody.

It made my job
easier, probably--

so I could concentrate
with my interviews
when they were phone interviews.

But it didn't help
my social skills.

SPEAKER: Another unintended
consequence of cubicles.

CLEMENCIA VILLAMIL: You
know, I'm 5-feet tall.

So for somebody who
is 5 feet, a cubicle
is really, really a bad idea.

Because most cubicles
must be about 5-something.

So everybody could see over
the cubicles and socialize.

And there I am having to go
around every single cubicle
to see somebody else.

SPEAKER: The concept
of telecommuting

was first proposed during the
oil crisis of the early 1970s,

as an alternative to
gas-guzzling commutes.

By the 1980s and
'90s, technology

had made teleworking
viable for more jobs.

And many companies
began experimenting

with remote-work programs,
to reduce office expenses

and offer employees
greater flexibility.

REX GOODMAN: I've
really never worked

in an office, my
entire adult life.

SPEAKER: Rex Goodman
was a remote sales

rep for United
Airlines in the 1980s.

He plotted-out his sales
visits with little blue dots

on road maps and
hunted for pay phones,

checking-in with the office
receptionist for messages.

REX GOODMAN: There was no voice
mail or anything at that point.

And then return those calls
to the client that called you.

But the first thing you had
to do was find a pay phone.

SPEAKER: Rex's life changed
when cell phones came along.

He got his first
one in 1995, but it
wasn't an immediate liberation.

REX GOODMAN: Kind of
amusingly, we really weren't
allowed to use them that.
Minutes were so extensive.

SPEAKER: In 1936,
Alan Turing published

a paper the proposed something
called an automatic machine.

If someone could encode
a problem on paper tape,
Turing's machine could solve it.

And in the decades
that followed,

computers slowly made
their way into offices.

In the 1950s,
companies could rent

gigantic IBM data-processing
machines, for about $15,000
a month.

That's the equivalent
of about $160,000 today.

By the 1980s, computers were
much more common in offices,

but you needed specialized
skills to use them.

ROY ILLSLEY: You used to have
to go to a computer room.

You used to have to sort a
program using tape or cards.

So you would take your cards,
load them in the card reader,

load your program,
execute your program,

run it on a screen and
keyboard in the computer room.

Take your printout
back to your desk,

and then trawl
through the errors.

And then three-days
later, repeat it.

SPEAKER: Roy Illsley, who
worked in IT in the '80s,

also noticed that
personal computers changed
the way people worked together.

ROY ILLSLEY: When you go back
before the personal computer

was there, you didn't have
a desk with a computer.

You had to go and
talk to people.

But as soon as you got
the personal computer,
your mobility slowed down.

You stopped walking
in, doing stuff.

You became a lot more
insular, because you

were focused on the task at
something-- sat there doing it.

And when email came,
it was even worse.

SPEAKER: In 1965,
researchers at MIT

discovered how to share files
and messages between computers.

But it wasn't until the mid-'90s
that free electronic mail

started to become
widely available.

ROY ILLSLEY: Nobody got up
to go and talk to somebody.
You'd send them an email.

They were probably only
three desks down from you,

but you wouldn't go
and speak to them.
You'd send them an email.

PETA SWEET: It's just a complete
shock was instantaneous way.

It was an instantaneous
way of communicating,

without having to go through
somebody's secretary, or book
a meeting.

So it sort of felt a
little bit scary, really.

SPEAKER: Today, we
rarely think about email.
It just is.

But as with so many
other innovations

that have revolutionized
the way we work,

electronic mail was once
uncomfortably, excitingly new.

LUCY GILL-SIMMEN: I
remember one day this guy

walking in to the office
that I was working in

and asking me to
move out of the way,

because he needed to get me on
to electronic mail, or email.

And I didn't really
know what this meant.

But it basically
meant that I would

be able to send
messages electronically
to people all over the world.

And so I said, oh, let's try
the colleague in New Mexico.
I came back in, in the morning.

And I always remember this
voice saying, you've got mail.
And I had one email.

Hey, Lucy, good
to hear from you.

And I remember just
like being completely
blown away with excitement.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
